awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Wintertime INvestigation of Transport, Emissions, and Reactivity (WINTER)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund the deployment of a research aircraft in a study to observe wintertime pollution in the Northeastern United States.  While there have been a number of studies that have sampled atmospheric chemistry in the warm season, there have been relatively few studies in the cool season and none with the advanced instrumentation that the scientific community now possesses.  This is important because the processes that affect how much pollution is created and how far it travels depends significantly on water vapor and sunlight, both of which are dramatically different in summer and winter.  This study will examine how these processes work in cold temperatures and low sunlight and provide input to numerical modelers to help improve forecasts and provide guidance for policymakers on how to best reduce harmful air pollution events.

The Wintertime Investigations of Transport, Emissions, and Reactivity (WINTER) project will take place in early 2015.  The main goal is to provide observations needed to develop a deeper understanding of the chemical and physical processes which govern the spatial distribution of anthropogenic pollutants during winter.  The researchers argue that a majority of observations in polluted mid-latitude regions have been in summer, when plentiful sunlight and water vapor lead to the rapid oxidation of NOx and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) by OH.  In the winter months when OH concentrations are much lower and temperatures are colder, different oxidation pathways are expected to be more important. This leads to the slower oxidation of reactive pollutants such as nitrogen oxides, VOCs and sulfur dioxide, resulting in longer atmospheric lifetimes and therefore the transport of these species over wider geographic areas.  The colder winter temperatures also change the equilibrium gas-particle partitioning of semi-volatile species (e.g. HNO3) favoring the formation of particles and resulting in seasonal changes in dominant aerosol components. For example, studies have shown that inorganic nitrogen is a much higher component of the aerosol in the winter.  The three primary research objectives are:  1)  Characterize the chemical transformations of wintertime emissions via multiphase, nocturnal, and photochemical processes, 2) Assess the dominant mechanisms of secondary aerosol formation and quantify the geographical distribution of inorganic and organic aerosol types during winter, and 3) Constrain wintertime emission inventories of key pollutants for urban areas, power plants, and agricultural areas, and characterize their export over the North Atlantic.  In addition to the broader impacts stated above, a significant number of students would be involved in the field campaign and data analysis activities.  Outreach activities will include a media day, visits by K-12 students, and project updates through social media.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the design and execution of the Wintertime INvestigation of Transport, Emissions and Reactivity (WINTER) campaign, and associated scientific analyses. The campaign utilized the NSF/NCAR C-130 reserach aircraft during Feb - March 2018, based out of NASA Langley Research Center. The campaign had the following objectives:

(1) to characterize the chemical transformations of wintertime emissions with an equal focus on nocturnal and multiphase processes as on photochemistry;

(2) to assess the dominant mechanism of secondary aerosol formation and quantify the geographical distribution of inorganic and organic aerosol types during winter;

(3) to provide constraints on wintertime emission inventories for urban areas, power plants and agricultural areas, and characterize the export pathways of primary pollutants to the North Atlantic.

The campaign was a collaboration between the University of Washington, Colorado University, Georgia Insitute of Technology, University of California, Berkeley, University of Maryland, North Carolina State Agricultural and Technical Univeristy, NOAA Earth System Laboratory, and NASA Goddard Space Flight Center.

Outcomes that addrss Intellectual Merit

National inventories of emissions of nitrogen oxides and sulfur dioxide pollutants are relatively accurate during wintertime, while significant gaps remain in descripts of reactive volatile organic compounds and ammonia.

>95% of particulate matter less than 2.5 micron in size (PM2.5) over the WINTER domain is "secondary", formed in the atmosphere from chemistry of primary pollutants. About 2/3 is inorganic (nitrate, sulfate, and ammonium) and 1/3 being organic. Slightly more than a third is the result of multi-phase chemistry involving reactions on aerosol or in cloud droplets.

Thermodyanmics of nitric acid gas-particle partitioning appear to be well described down to 260 K. The nightttime chemistry of dinitrogen pentoxide was a substantial source of particle nitrate, but uncertainties remain in how best to describe its reaction efficiency and reaction products such as ClNO2 in models

Secondary organic aerosol (SOA) represented >70% of organic aerosol mass, was correlated with photochemical age downwind of anthropogenic CO emissions, and increased with photochemical aging timescales similar to that observed in summertime urban areas. The volatile organic compounds which react to form this SOA during winter remain largely unknown.T

The chemical system which governs conversion of primary emissions such as SO2, NOx, and VOC into secondary aerosol is highly coupled, with significant feedbacks which affect the effecacy of emissions reductions. For example, decreasing SO2 emissions leads to lower acidity aerosol, which leads to a greater fraction of HNO3 to partition into aerosol, such that nitrate aerosol mass concentrations can stay nearly constant even though NOx emissions have also decreased.

The dominant sources of primary radicals, which initiate the photochemical oxidation of pollutants are rather different from that in summer, including formaldehyde, nitrous acid, and nitryl chloride. Most air quality models do not have adequate representation of these radical sources due to uncertain emissions and multiphase chemistry governs their abundance.

Broader Impacts

At the University of Washington, we have engaged four graduate students, three of which are women, and a postdoctoral research fellow in the collection and analysis of WINTER data, modeling, and manuscript publication. These students have also given oral presentations both in local seminars, and two have given oral presentations at national meetings. The collaborative project as a whole engaged several more students and postdoctoral fellows.

We have published more than 18 peer-reviewed articles on the results, some in broad audience journals such as Proceedings of National Academy of Sciences and Geophysical Research Letters.

This award helped  characterize and further explore the capabilities of the HRToF-CIMS instrument which the PI pioneered for use aboard research aircraft. Our demonstration during WINTER has led to its deployment aboard other aircraft and other NSF C130 campaigns.

The WINTER data set is publicly available, and research groups at private universities as well as government agencies are using the data set to test their models and hypotheses regarding wintertime atmospheric chemistry.

Many air quality and chemistry-climate models are used to develop estimates of exposure to pollution, which in turn then inform heath effect models or to test the effects of certain emissions regulatory policies on climate-relevant gases and aerosol abundance. The WINTER data and related scientific findings impact these disciplines by providing both a rare collection of data able to test these models, as well as improvements to the descriptions of pollutants and climate-relevant composition based on comparing the observations to existing model frameworks.
